This is a list of [[food desert]] issues and solutions by [[country]].
== Africa ==
African food deserts are complex due to accelerated [[urbanization]], the various ways individuals acquire food through formal and informal food economy markets, familial dynamics of the household, and African social, political and economic effects.<ref name=":6" /> African food deserts have been defined as "poor, often informal, urban neighborhoods characterized by high [[Food security|food insecurity]] and low dietary diversity, with multiple markets and market and non-market food sources but variable household access to food."<ref name=":6">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s12132-014-9225-5 |title=Africa's Urban Food Deserts |journal=Urban Forum |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=143–51 |year=2014 |last1=Battersby |first1=Jane |last2=Crush |first2=Jonathan }}</ref>
The definition of a food desert often relates to the distance between residents and the nearest supermarket. In Western nations, supermarkets prevail over traders and vendors but food sourcing methods within Africa are reversed. Certain regions have an informal economy where traders and vendors are available within the areas they live and other local areas.<ref name=":6" /> [[Urban agriculture]] also plays a big role within Africa as [[pastoralism]] is widely practiced – populations raise their own livestock and grow their own food creating informal rural-urban food transfer systems. These practices vary throughout Africa but do not increase food security and limits community resources to create a food desert.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/19320248.2012.702448 |title=The Crisis of Food Insecurity in African Cities |journal=Journal of Hunger & Environmental Nutrition |volume=7 |issue=2–3 |pages=271–92 |year=2012 |last1=Crush |first1=Jonathan |last2=Frayne |first2=Bruce |last3=Pendleton |first3=Wade }}</ref> Low-income populations are still more inclined to source food in these ways, however supermarket growth in both urban and rural areas is cutting off these food sourcing methods and worsening food security.<ref name=Battersby2012 />
Accordingly, households within the same food desert source food differently.<ref name=":6" /> Most neighborhoods have a mix of various income levels. Those with higher incomes have better access to transportation and are more likely to shop at the nearest grocery store. Lower income households tend to stick to sourcing food from local vendors with more limited operating hours or through pastoralism.<ref name=Battersby2012>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1468-0467.2012.00401.x |title=Beyond the Food Desert: Finding Ways to Speak About Urban Food Security in South Africa |journal=Geografiska Annaler: Series B, Human Geography |volume=94 |issue=2 |pages=141–59 |year=2012 |last1=Battersby |first1=Jane }}</ref> The African Food Security Urban Network (AFSUN) found that nearly 70% of poor urban African households sourced part of their food needs from vendors and traders and 79% of these households utilized a supermarket. When these studies took frequency into account, it was found that poor Africans use informal vendors more often for most of their needs and go to supermarkets to buy large quantities of a [[Staple food|staple]].<ref name=":6" />
With economic growth contributing to the building of supermarkets and other urban renewal practices, land space is taken from pastoral communities that grow and harvest their own food and reduces the resources vendors use to attain the products they sell, limiting their business practices and giving rise to food deserts in Africa.<ref name=Battersby2012 /> Modern food systems in towns and cities are coming about rapidly changing and destabilizing the already high food insecurity practices already in place.
The AFSUN survey results indicate a wide variety of factors, such as gender, income, and education affect access to nutritious food.<ref name=":6" /> Households headed by a man have greater access to food than those headed by a woman.<ref name=":6" /> This is due to various socio-political towards women that do not affect modern, Western women who have more access to financial opportunities. In Africa, female heads of households are twice as likely to be food insecure than men. Women have less mobility within Africa and thus rely more on less secure food sourcing practices.
=== South Africa === ==== Transportation problems ==== African cities suffer from a large degree of fragmentation which leads to the poor having to utilize public transportation to travel large distances, spending up to 3 hours a day in transit. With much of the day wasted in transit, poor Africans have less time to spend on shopping or preparing food which forces them to buy more expensive, less nutritious, already prepared foods from either [[Street food|street vendors]] or restaurants.<ref name=Battersby2012 /> This fragmentation and mobility also leads to many poor Africans shopping for groceries in places outside their township. A study in Soweto, Johannesburg in 2004 showed most urban poor spend about 50% of their expenses in places outside of the towns in which they reside.<ref name=":6" />
==== Impacts ====
The 1995 Income and Expenditure Survey conducted in South Africa assessed an urban food insecurity rate of 27 percent, relative to the rural rate of 62 percent.<ref>Central Statistical Service. "Income and Expenditure Survey 1995." DataFirst. N.p., 25 Oct. 2012. Web. 10 Nov. 2016. https://www.datafirst.uct.ac.za/dataportal/index.php/catalog/264</ref> Later studies such as the National Food Consumption Survey of 1999<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1079/PHN2005816 |title=The National Food Consumption Survey (NFCS): South Africa, 1999 |journal=Public Health Nutrition |volume=8 |issue=5 |year=2007 |last1=Labadarios |first1=D |last2=Steyn |first2=NP |last3=Maunder |first3=E |last4=MacIntryre |first4=U |last5=Gericke |first5=G |last6=Swart |first6=R |last7=Huskisson |first7=J |last8=Dannhauser |first8=A |last9=Vorster |first9=HH |last10=Nesmvuni |first10=AE |last11=Nel |first11=JH }}</ref> and South African Social Attitudes Survey of 2008 independently assessed the urban food insecurity rate to be roughly half of that of the rural rate.<ref>Human Sciences Research Council. "South African Social Attitudes Survey 2008." DataFirst. N.p., 1 July 2014. Web. 10 Nov. 2016. https://www.datafirst.uct.ac.za/dataportal/index.php/catalog/488</ref>
A 2000 survey conducted on rural [[Eastern Cape]], rural [[Western Cape]] and urban [[Cape Town]] assessed [[Food security|food insecurity]] to be 83, 69, and 81 percent, respectively. This survey took into account other urban African factors than distribution of market retailers such as supermarkets to include the tendency of residents to utilize formal food sources over informal like agriculture and local markets.<ref name=Battersby2012 />
== Australia ==
===Socioeconomic Disparities===
In Australia jobs are organized into low or high class using Australian and New Zealand Standard Classification of Occupations (ANZSCO) which considers skills,education,and experience to place the job.The location of food deserts are put into areas where peoples jobs and income are considered on the low side of the spectrum.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zarnowiecki, |first1=Dorota |title=Socioeconomic Disparities in Food Consumption and Availability. |journal=Nutridate 28 |date=May 2017 |volume=2 |accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> In Western Australia, a dearth of high quality and affordable fruit and vegetables in isolated regions was identified as one factor limiting consumption along with produce seasonality.<ref name="Western Australia Study">{{cite journal |doi= 10.1111/j.1467-842X.2005.tb00070.x |pmid=15915624 |title= Health working with Industry to promote fruit and vegetables: a case study of the Western Australian Fruit and Vegetable Campaign with reflection on effectiveness and inter-sectoral action |journal= Australian and New Zealand Journal of Public Health |volume= 29 |pages=176–182 |year= 2005 |last1=Miller |first1=Margaret |last2= Pollard |first2=Christina }}</ref> A 2014 review found that the less populous and very remote areas of the state had fewer grocery stores and higher prices for fruit, vegetables and dairy than in the city. Economically it is reported that in areas with low income families would have to spend 56% of their income of just buying healthy food for their families. lack or availability to fresher food leads to unhealthy food consumption resulting in what is described as a "obesogenic" neighborhood which simply means that the environments food surroundings do not support healthy eating.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zarnowiecki, |first1=Dorota |title=Socioeconomic Disparities in Food Consumption and Availability. |journal=Nutridate 28 |date=May 2017 |volume=2 |accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> Of these stores, 20% did not generally supply produce that met all quality standards with a few exceptions, unlike urban areas with exceptions for lettuce and green beans in Perth.<ref>{{cite journal |doi= 10.6133/apjcn.2014.23.4.12 |pmid=25516329 |title= Geographic factors as determinants of food security: a Western Australian food pricing and quality study |journal= Asia Pacific Journal of Clinical Nutrition |volume= 23 |issue=4 |pages=703–713 |year= 2014 |last1= Pollard |first1=Christina M |last2= Landrigan |first2=Timothy J |last3=Ellies |first3=Pernilla L|last4= Kerr |first4=Deborah A|last5= Lester |first5=Matthew L|last6= Goodchild |first6=Stanley E }}</ref> Geographical data were not analyzed for prevalence of low income residents to define areas as food deserts.
===Effects===
A five-year campaign to increase access to healthy foods started in 1990 and led by the Department of Health in Western Australia and industry groups had mixed success.<ref name="Western Australia Study"/> By also creating community programs that provide food and transport services to families that live the the 1,600 meter radius away from a grocery store. And also focusing on prevention of diabetes and diabetes management.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Dragging the chain on making a difference |journal=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=2018 |url=https://eds-b-ebscohost-com.ezproxy.xula.edu/eds/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=6eb57ebb-49ce-4bc1-a374-aac04b4fbe06%40pdc-v-sessmgr01&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmU%3d#AN=edsgcl.547635157&db=edsgov |accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> The minor health effects that can come from not having sustainable food options can be childhood obesity and even health issues like asthma.Although long term health effects can come from the minor health problems like heart disease caused from the obesity and type 2 diabetes. And if these bad habits continue unchanged a person effected by these disease could die prematurely.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=ABC |title=Experts Identify Australia’s Fresh Food Dead Zones with Big Health Problems. |date=October 18 |accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref> The department later developed a new private/public partnership to address access and consumption of fruit and vegetables.<ref name = "Western Australia audit">{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1743-8462-5-27 |pmid=19108736 |pmc=2621230 |title=Selecting interventions to promote fruit and vegetable consumption: From policy to action, a planning framework case study in Western Australia |journal=Australia and New Zealand Health Policy |volume=5 |pages=27 |year=2008 |last1=Pollard |first1=Christina M |last2=Lewis |first2=Janette M |last3=Binns |first3=Colin W }}</ref> A 2008 audit found some progress generated as a result in incentive's fruit and vegetable access, but no headway in identifying and addressing any supply issues in development planning or elucidating cost, quality and access issues for remote, rural and urban areas.<ref name = "Western Australia audit"/>
== Europe == "European (non-UK) food access research also frequently highlights the problem of poverty in relation to accessing a healthy diet." French researches have noted that lower income consumers have a tendency to reach for more affordable items such as high caloric foods, (i.e. cereals, sweets, and added fats) instead of nutrient rich single source foods.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1108/00070701211202403 |title=Access to healthy food in Nantes, France |journal=British Food Journal |volume=114 |issue=2 |pages=224–38 |year=2012 |last1=Shaw |first1=Hillary }}</ref>
=== United Kingdom ===
British food deserts can be broadly classified into twelve geographical types, based on the interaction of socioeconomic factors of physical access to shops, financial access (affordability of) healthy food, and attitudes towards consumption of healthy food, the desire to consume it rather than fast / convenience food, possession of cooking skills, that is, psychological access. These twelve neighbourhood types are 1) inner city executive flat areas (too fast lifestyle to cook healthily), 2) inner city ethnic minority areas (cost of food vs low wages), 3) inner city deprived areas severed by main roads from retail areas (poor physical access), 4) declining suburban areas (shops closing, poor physical access to supermarkets), 5) planned local authority housing areas (low income, and shops often lack fresh produce), 6) student residence areas (preference for fast food outlets, little demand for fresh produce), 7) Wealthy suburban areas, most shop by car, but some less mobile pensioners with no car. Areas 8 – 12 are rural food deserts. 8) is small market town centres losing trade to out-of-town supermarkets, leaving the car-less without easy access, 9) market town suburbs, poor bus service to centre perhaps 1 or 2 miles (2 – 3 kilometres) distant, 10), smaller rural towns, lack full range of fresh produce, 11) remoter villages, no shop, and under-served by mobile shops, 12) dispersed settlements, no focal point for shop.<ref>(Shaw H, The Consuming Geographies of Food: Diet, Food Deserts and Obesity, 2014, Routledge, 2014, pp. 132–133), see also http://www.fooddeserts.org</ref>
Furey et al. describes food desert creation as arising where "high competition from large chain supermarkets has created a void".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1023/A:1015218502547 |year=2001 |last1=Furey |first1=Sinéad |title=An investigation of the potential existence of 'food deserts' in rural and urban areas of Northern Ireland |journal=Agriculture and Human Values |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=447–457 |last2=Strugnell |first2=Christopher |last3=McIlveen |first3=Heather }}</ref>
== North America ==
=== United States === [[File:Food Deserts in US (2010).jpg|thumb|This map depicts food deserts in the United States by counties as reported by the USDA in 2010.]]
==== Implications ==== Food deserts are defined by a [[Supermarket shortage|shortage of supermarkets]] and other stores that carry affordable healthful food.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ers.usda.gov/webdocs/publications/ap036/12716_ap036_1_.pdf|title=Access to Affordable and Nutritious Food: Measuring and Understanding Food Deserts and Their Consequences|last=|first=|date=Jun 2009|website=|publisher=United States Department of Agriculture Economic Research Service|access-date=13 Nov 2016}}</ref> Audit research suggests that supermarkets are the most effective way to supply communities with a wide selection of fresh and relatively affordable healthful food. Moreover, they are typically open year-round, provide convenient hours of operation and generally accept food stamps from the [http://www.fns.usda.gov/snap/supplemental-nutrition-assistance-program-snap Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)] and [http://www.fns.usda.gov/wic/women-infants-and-children-wic Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC)].<ref>Neckerman, K. M., Bader, M., Purciel, M., & Yousefzadeh, P. (2009). Measuring Food Access in Urban Areas. Built Environment and Health . Neighborhood Revitalization. (2011). Retrieved 3 10, 2011, from The District of Columbia: http://dmped.dc.gov/DC/DMPED/Programs+and+Initiatives/Neighborhood+Revitalization</ref> Small-scale, full-service food markets could play a role in increasing community food security.<ref>Short, Anne & Guthman, Julie & Raskin, Samuel. 2007. Food Deserts, Oases, or Mirages? Small Markets and Community Food Security in the San Francisco Bay Area. Journal of Planning and Education Research 2007, 26:352.</ref>
===== Affordability ===== Compared to residents of higher-income neighborhoods, low [[socioeconomic status]] (SES) individuals tend to have diets higher in meat and [[Convenience food|processed foods]] and a lower intake of fruits and vegetables.<ref name="yeh">Ming-Chen Yeh and David L. Katz. "Food, Nutrition, and the Health of Urban Populations". In ''Cities and the Health of the Public'' (Nicholas Freudenberg, Sandro Galea, and David Vlahov, eds.). Vanderbilt University Press (2006), pp. 106-127. {{ISBN|0-8265-1512-6}}.</ref> They are more likely to purchase inexpensive fats and sugars over fresh fruits and vegetables that are more expensive on a per calorie basis.<ref name="Story09">{{cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev.publhealth.29.020907.090926 |pmid=18031223 |title=Creating Healthy Food and Eating Environments: Policy and Environmental Approaches |journal=Annual Review of Public Health |volume=29 |pages=253–72 |year=2008 |last1=Story |first1=Mary |last2=Kaphingst |first2=Karen M. |last3=Robinson-o'Brien |first3=Ramona |last4=Glanz |first4=Karen }}</ref><ref name="The New York Times">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/18/health/research/pairing-of-food-deserts-and-obesity-challenged-in-studies.html|title=Studies Question the Pairing of Food Deserts and Obesity|date=17 April 2012|work=The New York Times |last1=Kolata|first1=Gina}}</ref> On average, the most energy-dense foods only cost $1.76 per 1,000 calories, compared to $18.16 per 1,000 calories for low-energy nutritious foods.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jada.2007.09.009 |pmid=18060892 |title=The Rising Cost of Low-Energy-Density Foods |journal=Journal of the American Dietetic Association |volume=107 |issue=12 |pages=2071–6 |year=2007 |last1=Monsivais |first1=Pablo |last2=Drewnowski |first2=Adam }}</ref> This is one reason cited for why low-income populations and minorities are more predisposed to suffer from obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular disease.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.foodispower.org/food-deserts/|title=Food Deserts |publisher= Food Empowerment Project|location=Cotati, CA |access-date=July 14, 2017}}</ref>
Income may play a big role in determining the eating habits of families in food deserts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/11/food-deserts/414534/|title=Are Food Deserts to Blame for America's Poor Eating Habits?|last=Cortright|first=Joe|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Those impacted by food deserts are typically impoverished,<ref name=":1" /> with an average income between $5,000 and $20,000 annually.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Dubowitz |first1=Tamara |last2=Zenk |first2=Shannon N. |last3=Ghosh-Dastidar |first3=Bonnie |last4=Cohen |first4=Deborah A. |last5=Beckman |first5=Robin |last6=Hunter |first6=Gerald |last7=Steiner |first7=Elizabeth D. |last8=Collins |first8=Rebecca L. |date=August 2015 |title=Healthy food access for urban food desert residents: examination of the food environment, food purchasing practices, diet and BMI |journal=Public Health Nutrition |volume=18 |issue=12 |pages=2220–2230 |doi=10.1017/s1368980014002742|pmc=4457716 }}</ref> According to the USDA, "Research that considers the prices paid for the same food across household income levels indicates that while some of the very poorest households—those earning less than $8,000 per year—may pay between 0.5 percent and 1.3 percent more for their groceries than households earning slightly more, households earning between $8,000 and $30,000 tend to pay the lowest prices for groceries, whereas higher income households pay significantly higher prices."<ref name=":9">Access to affordable and nutritious food: Measuring and understanding food deserts and their consequences: Report to Congress. Washington, D.C.: U.S. Dept. of Agriculture, Economic Research Service. Jun 2009. Web. 10 Nov 2016.</ref>
{{main|Supermarket shortage}} Chain supermarkets benefit from economies of scale to offer consumers low prices, but are less prevalent in low-income urban areas. In the United States, the number of supermarkets in low income neighborhoods is approximately 30% less than in the highest-income neighborhoods.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1745-6606.1999.tb00071.x |jstor=23859959 |ssrn=2026583 |title=Do the Poor Pay More for Food? An Analysis of Grocery Store Availability and Food Price Disparities |journal=Journal of Consumer Affairs |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=276–96 |year=1999 |last1=Chung |first1=Chanjin |last2=Myers |first2=Samuel L. }}</ref> Within cities, three times as many supermarkets are in wealthier neighborhoods than poorer ones.<ref name=yeh /> "Economies of scale, which is when the costs of operating a store decrease as store size increases, and economies of scope, which is when the costs decrease as more product variety increases, suggests that larger stores that offer greater variety can do so and offer lower prices. Both factors may account for the ability of larger stores to survive more easily than smaller stores."<ref name="bitler" /> A 2008 book noted that 22% of the chain supermarkets in Minneapolis were located in the inner city compared to more than 50% of the non-chain stores.<ref>Winne, M. (2008). Closing the Food Gap: Resetting the Table in the Land of Plenty. Beacon Press.{{page needed|date=November 2016}}</ref> In the end, a 1990 U.S. government report found that people in urban areas pay 3 to 37 percent more for the same groceries locally than they would in a suburban supermarket.<ref>{{cite book | last1 =Morland | first1 =Kimberly | last2 =Wing | first2 =Steve | chapter =7. Food Justice and Health in Communities of Color | editor-last =Bullard | editor-first =Robert D. | title =Growing Smarter: Achieving Livable Communities, Environmental Justice, and Regional Equity | publisher =The MIT Press | series =Urban and Industrial Environments | date =2007 | location =Cambridge, Massachusetts | pages =173 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=NAcmSchlTOYC&pg=PA173&lpg=PA173&dq=It+has+been+shown+that+urban+dwellers+pay+3%25+to+37%25+more+for+groceries+in+their+local+community+compared+to+suburban+residents+who+buy+the+same+goods+at+large+supermarkets.&source=bl&ots=X-T5h8hmC0&sig=XL6VFnDUkk58TZsUbQro-YNBcTc&hl=en&ei=T9hyTbCKOo32tgPUycjUCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false | isbn =978-0262524704 }}</ref>
In the absence of other grocery outlets, residents in low-income urban areas are often "forced to depend on small stores with limited selections of foods at substantially higher prices".<ref name=morland /> Fringe food retailers have market power to increase prices (around 30-60%) off a limited product selection dominated by processed foods.<ref name="bitler">{{cite conference|first1=Steven J.|last1=Haider|first2=Marianne|last2=Bitler|date=March 2009|title=An Economic View of Food Deserts in the United States|url=http://www.npc.umich.edu/news/events/food-access/final_bitler_haider.pdf|conference=Understanding the Economic Concepts and Characteristics of Food Access|conferenceurl=http://www.npc.umich.edu/news/events/food-access/index.php|publisher=National Poverty Center}}</ref> Research finds "retail prices for the same foods to be higher in deprived areas" that have a dearth of supermarkets and food stores.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Findings from the USDA support that prices for similar goods are on average higher at convenience stores than at supermarkets.<ref name=":12" /> As a result, people of low SES ultimately spend up to 37% more on their food purchases.<ref name="morland">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/s0749-3797(01)00403-2 |pmid=11777675 |title=Neighborhood characteristics associated with the location of food stores and food service places |journal=American Journal of Preventive Medicine |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=23–9 |year=2002 |last1=Morland |first1=Kimberly |last2=Wing |first2=Steve |last3=Diez Roux |first3=Ana |last4=Poole |first4=Charles }}</ref>
Smaller communities have fewer choices in food retailers. Resident small grocers struggle to be profitable partly due to low sales numbers, which make it difficult to meet wholesale food suppliers' minimum purchasing requirements.<ref name=VerPloeg2009>{{cite book |last=Ver Ploeg |first= Michele |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ChwzY1-x_6QC|title=Access to Affordable and Nutritious Food: Measuring and Understanding Food Deserts and Their Consequences: Report to Congress|publisher=DIANE Publishing |year=2009 |isbn=978-1-4379-2134-2 }}</ref> The lack of competition and sales volume can result in higher food costs.<ref name="smithmorton">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jneb.2008.06.008 |pmid=19411051 |title=Rural Food Deserts: Low-income Perspectives on Food Access in Minnesota and Iowa |journal=Journal of Nutrition Education and Behavior |volume=41 |issue=3 |pages=176–87 |year=2009 |last1=Smith |first1=Chery |last2=Morton |first2=Lois W. }}</ref><ref name=VerPloeg2009/> For example, in New Mexico the same basket of groceries that cost rural residents $85, cost urban residents only $55.<ref name=policylink>{{cite web |url=http://policylink.org/sites/default/files/FINALGroceryGap.pdf |title=The Grocery Gap |first1=Sarah |last1=Treuhaft |first2=Allison |last2=Karpyn |publisher=PolicyLink |year=2010 }}</ref> However, this is not true for all rural areas. A study in Iowa showed that grocers in four rural counties had lower costs on key foods that make up a nutritionally balanced diet than did larger supermarkets outside these food deserts (greater than 20 miles away).<ref name="Morton2007">{{cite journal |year=2007 |title=Starved for access: life in rural America's food deserts |url=http://www.ruralsociology.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/Rural-Realities-1-4.pdf |journal=Rural Realities |publisher=Rural Sociological Society |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=1–10 |last1=Morton |first1=Lois Wright |last2=Blanchard |first2=Troy C. }}</ref>
Grocery stores in low income communities have less variety.<ref name=":0" /> Small rural grocers and stores in areas where consumers are less interested in buying produce will carry less fruits and vegetables because they are more expensive compared to processed foods, especially in food deserts. This relates to the problem of "food swamps", regions that lack healthy and nutritious food choices.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Hui Luan|author2=Jane Law|author3=Matthew Quick|title=Identifying food deserts and swamps based on relative healthy food access: a spatio-temporal Bayesian approach|journal=International Journal of Health Geographics|volume=14|pages=37|pmc=4696295|year=2015|doi=10.1186/s12942-015-0030-8|pmid=26714645}}</ref> Even when healthy foods are available, they may not be affordable for many residents in poorer communities.<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fn-an/nutrition/pol/som-ex-sum-environ-eng.php|title=Measuring the Food Environment in Canada|last=|first=|date=11 Oct 2013|website=Food and Nutrition|publisher=Health Canada|access-date=13 Nov 2016}}</ref> Higher prices on healthy food than unhealthy potentially affects obesity rates.<ref name ="Ghosh">{{cite journal | last1 = Ghosh-Dastidar | first1 = B. | last2 = Cohen | first2 = D. | last3 = Hunter | first3 = G. | last4 = Zenk | first4 = S. N. | last5 = Huang | first5 = C. | last6 = Beckman | first6 = R. | last7 = Dubowitz | first7 = T. | year = 2014 | title = Distance to store, food prices, and obesity in urban food deserts | url = | journal = American Journal of Preventive Medicine | volume = 47 | issue = 5| pages = 587–595 | doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2014.07.005| pmc = 4205193 }}</ref>
In a study on urban food environments, participants described the lack of supermarkets as a "practical impediment to healthful food purchase and a symbol of their neighborhoods' social and economic struggles".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11524-010-9441-9 |pmid=20354910 |pmc=2871079 |title=The Contribution of Urban Foodways to Health Disparities |journal=Journal of Urban Health |volume=87 |issue=3 |pages=381–93 |year=2010 |last1=Cannuscio |first1=Carolyn C. |last2=Weiss |first2=Eve E. |last3=Asch |first3=David A. }}</ref>
===== Health outcomes ===== There are diet and health implications for those who live in areas where nutritious food is not readily available; some claims, such as linking food deserts with obesity in children, are disputed.<ref name="Story09" /><ref name="The New York Times"/><ref name="ford" />
A summary report by [[The Colorado Health Foundation]] concluded that individuals with access to [[supermarket]]s tend to have healthier diets and a lower risk of [[Chronic condition|chronic disease]] such as [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]].<ref name="Beck, C. 2010">{{cite web |last1= Beck |first1= Christina |title= Food Access in Colorado |year=2010 |url=http://www.coloradohealth.org/sites/default/files/documents/2017-01/TCHF_Food_Access_Report_web-Food%20Access%20in%20CO.pdf |publisher=Colorado Health Foundation, Denver, Colorado }}</ref> Food deserts are correlated with many poor health outcomes. Other studies find a link between better access to supermarkets and lowered risk of [[obesity]]. As well, better access to convenience stores is associated with a higher risk of obesity.<ref name=":12" /> * A lack of plant-based foods (fruits, vegetables, nuts, whole grains) correlates with an increased risk of [[cardiovascular disease]].<ref name=":12" /> * Beverages sweetened with sugar are linked to a higher risk of [[obesity]], [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], and [[cardiovascular disease]].<ref name=":12" /> *Studies on food deserts and [[type 2 diabetes mellitus]] demonstrate that areas with limited access to nutritious food are associated with an increased prevalence of type 2 diabetes .<ref>Fitzgerald N, Hromi-Fiedler A, Segura-Perez S, Perez-Escamilla R. Food insecurity is related to increased risk of type 2 diabetes among Latinas. Ethn Dis. 2011;21(3):328–34.</ref><ref>Seligman HK, Bindman AB, Vittinghoff E, Kanaya AM, Kushel MB.  Food insecurity is associated with diabetes mellitus: results from the National Health Examination and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 1999–2002. J Gen Intern Med 2007;22:1018–1023</ref><ref>Gucciardi E, Vogt JA, DeMelo M, Stewart DE.  Exploration of the relationship between household food insecurity and diabetes in Canada. Diabetes Care. 2009 Dec; 32(12):2218-24</ref>
Studies show that food insecurity can impact the health of elderly adults including lower BMI, limited activity and malnutrition.<ref name="Fitzpatrick 19–40">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/ajae/aav044 |title=The Impact of Food Deserts on Food Insufficiency and SNAP Participation among the Elderly |journal=American Journal of Agricultural Economics |volume=98 |pages=19–40 |year=2016 |last1=Fitzpatrick |first1=Katie |last2=Greenhalgh-Stanley |first2=Nadia |last3=Ver Ploeg |first3=Michele }}</ref> An elderly person without consistent access to enough fruits and vegetables and the proper variety of nutrients are at higher risk for health problems and future ailments.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.maturitas.2013.05.005 |pmid=23769545 |pmc=3713183 |title=Fruit and vegetable intake among older adults: A scoping review |journal=Maturitas |volume=75 |issue=4 |pages=305–12 |year=2013 |last1=Nicklett |first1=Emily J. |last2=Kadell |first2=Andria R. }}</ref>
A 2010 study inversely correlated distance from supermarkets and decreased availability of healthy foods with increases in body mass index and risk of obesity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ctdatahaven.org/know/index.php/Research_Availability_Healthy_Food_FoodDeserts |title=Review: Research on Availability of Healthy Food in Food Deserts. Web-based document at DataHaven with summary of numerous recent studies on food desert impacts on health. |accessdate=2011-02-01 |date=2011-01-31 |publisher=DataHaven}}</ref> Among elderly people in particular, malnutrition caused by inadequate access to food can lead to other health risks. For those suffering from weight loss and undernutrition, risks include increased and longer hospitalizations, early admission to long term care facilities, and overall increased morbidity and mortality.<ref name="martin">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/gerona/61.9.927 |title=Nutritional Risk and Low Weight in Community-Living Older Adults: A Review of the Literature (1995–2005) |journal=The Journals of Gerontology Series A: Biological Sciences and Medical Sciences |volume=61 |issue=9 |pages=927–34 |year=2006 |last1=Thompson Martin |first1=C. |last2=Kayser-Jones |first2=J. |last3=Stotts |first3=N. |last4=Porter |first4=C. |last5=Froelicher |first5=E. S. }}</ref> Nutritional disorders with co-morbidities are the ninth most frequent diagnostic category among hospitalized rural elderly Medicare beneficiaries. Elderly adults struggling with obesity and overnutrition related to limited food choices are at risk of exacerbating existing chronic conditions, such as heart disease and diabetes, and increased functional decline.<ref name="martin" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1532-5415.2002.50220.x |pmid=12028181 |title=Obesity is Associated with Functional Decline in Community-Dwelling Rural Older Persons |journal=Journal of the American Geriatrics Society |volume=50 |issue=5 |pages=918–23 |year=2002 |last1=Jensen |first1=Gordon L. |last2=Friedmann |first2=Janet M. }}</ref>
While correlations have been found, the causal pathways are complex and not fully understood. Most studies on food environments and health are cross-sectional and thus cannot make causal conclusions. Improvements in research are needed before causal relationships can be explicitly defined.<ref name=":12" />
==== Transportation barriers to food access ==== According to 2010 reports from the USDA, approximately 29.7 million people (9.7% of the population) live in low-income areas that are more than 1 mile from a supermarket.<ref name=":12" /> Often the only close places for residents to purchase food are convenience stores or corner shops.<ref name="Bauer">Bauer, Katherine W. (2004, January 201). Price and Availability Matter. From The New York Times: https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2011/01/23/can-wal-mart-make-us-healthier/access-to-healthy-foods-and-lower-prices-matter</ref> A 2005 study utilizing GIS determined that among the most impoverished neighborhoods in [[Detroit]], African American ones were on average 1.1 miles farther from the nearest supermarket than white ones and 28% of their residents did not own a car.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2105/AJPH.2004.042150 |pmid=15798127 |pmc=1449238 |title=Neighborhood Racial Composition, Neighborhood Poverty, and the Spatial Accessibility of Supermarkets in Metropolitan Detroit |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=95 |issue=4 |pages=660–7 |year=2005 |last1=Zenk |first1=Shannon N. |last2=Schulz |first2=Amy J. |last3=Israel |first3=Barbara A. |last4=James |first4=Sherman A. |last5=Bao |first5=Shuming |last6=Wilson |first6=Mark L. }}</ref>
Urban areas usually have private and public transportation such as buses and trains available, but rural areas typically offer little to no public transportation even though the grocery stores are far from home.<ref name=":0" />
According to The Reinvestment Fund (TRF) and Low Supermarket Access areas (TRF 2012), the density of car ownerships is much lower in poorer communities.<ref name="Ploeg et al 2014">{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/aepp/ppu035 |title=Measuring Food Access and Food Deserts for Policy Purposes |journal=Applied Economic Perspectives and Policy |volume=37 |issue=2 |pages=205–25 |year=2014 |last1=Ver Ploeg |first1=M. |last2=Dutko |first2=P. |last3=Breneman |first3=V. }}</ref> Accessing healthy foods then becomes more difficult without reliable transportation. The Food Access Research Atlas (ERS 2013) maps out the measurement of food access in both low- and high-income communities. Under this measure, they point out the significance of number of cars within and a number of supermarkets in the area.<ref name="Ploeg et al 2014" />
And so, many people in low-income neighborhoods may spend more on transportation to bring their groceries home. [[The Colorado Health Foundation]] found that taxi cab drivers make more trips to grocery stores at the beginning of the month when food stamps are distributed and at the end of the month before they expire.<ref name="Beck, C. 2010" /> Fortunately, vehicle availability has improved over the past couple of decades has been helping disadvantaged residents overcome economic barriers and food access barriers in both rural and urban food deserts.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | author = Dutko, P. |url=http://www.choicesmagazine.org/choices-magazine/theme-articles/an-evaluation-of-food-deserts-in-america/food-deserts-suffer-persistent-socioeconomic-disadvantage | title = Food Deserts Suffer Persistent Socioeconomic Disadvantage | journal = Choices | volume = 27 | issue = 3 | pages = 1–4 | date = Fall 2012 }}</ref>
As of 2007, the elderly made up 7.5 million of the 50 million people living in rural America.<ref>Rural Health Information Hub. (2018). [https://www.ruralhealthinfo.org/topics/aging "Rural Aging"].</ref> The U.S Census website includes [https://www.ruralhealthinfo.org/rural-maps/mapfiles/population-over-age-65-county.jpg maps] showing the percentage of residents aged 65 and older.<ref>CensusScope. (2011). [Map illustration of percentage of Americans 65+]. Demographic Maps: An Aging Population. Retrieved from http://www.censusscope.org/us/map_65plus.html</ref> Of these elderly citizens, nearly a half million live in rural food deserts and are food insecure, while many more may be at risk.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} A study by Sharkey, et al. from seniors in the Brazos Valley showed that 14% couldn't make their monthly allotment of food supplies last, 13% couldn't eat balanced meals and 8.3% had to make their meals smaller or skip them.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1471-2318-10-32 |title=Food Access and Perceptions of the Community and Household Food Environment as Correlates of Fruit and Vegetable Intake among Rural Seniors |journal=BMC Geriatrics |volume=10 |year=2010 |last1=Sharkey |first1=Joseph R |last2=Johnson |first2=Cassandra M |last3=Dean |first3=Wesley R |pages=32 |pmid=20525208 |pmc=2892496}}</ref>
Elders are particularly affected by the obstacle of distance presented by rural food deserts. A survey by the [[interest group]] and [[insurer]] [[AARP]] reported that at age 75 and older, 83% of men and 60% of women still drive, down from 93% and 84% respectively at age 65 and lower than the 78% and 80% of the next lowest group, 16-24 year-olds.<ref>{{cite web |last1= Lynott |first1= Jana |last2=Figueiredo |first2= Carlos |title= How the Travel Patterns of Older Adults Are Changing: Highlights from the 2009 National Household Travel Survey |pages=4 |year=2011 |url=http://www.aarp.org/home-garden/transportation/info-04-2011/fs218-transportation.html|publisher=AARP Public Policy Institute, Washington, D.C. }}</ref> A [[Rural transport problem|lack of decent public transportation services]] in rural areas can therefore make it harder for elderly to shop.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sog.unc.edu/resources/microsites/building-assets-rural-future/improve-access-nutritious-food-rural-areas|title=Improve Access to Nutritious Food in Rural Areas|website=www.sog.unc.edu|access-date=2016-11-12}}</ref> As a result, it is 9.6% more probable that elders without a car living in a food desert will skip meals than those with one.<ref name="Fitzpatrick 19–40"/> Because of their lack of access to vehicles, older people are more likely to be dependent on those in their community to get food.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2752/152897903786769616 |title=Grocery Store Access Patterns in Rural Food Deserts |journal=Journal for the Study of Food and Society |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=35–48 |year=2003 |last1=Bitto |first1=Ella Annette |last2=Morton |first2=Lois Wright |last3=Oakland |first3=Mary Jan |last4=Sand |first4=Mary }}</ref>
==== Racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic disparities ==== [[File:Baltimorepiechart.jpg|thumb|Data from 2006 depicting the percentage of races living in areas with low access to healthy foods. This issue predominantly affects the African-American community.<ref name=policylink />]] Health disparities related to food access and consumption are associated with residential segregation, low incomes, and neighborhood deprivation. Morland ''et al.'' found that areas with a majority of convenience stores had a higher prevalence of overweight and obese individuals compared to areas with only supermarkets.<ref name=morland /> A lack of adequate food sources and limited transportation available to low-income communities may contribute to poor nutrition.<ref name=morland />
Research has documented differences in supermarket access between poor and non-poor urban areas. Baker ''et al.'' found that mixed-race areas were significantly less likely to have access to foods that adhere to a healthful diet compared to predominantly white, high income areas.<ref name="ford">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1753-4887.2008.00026.x |pmid=18366535 |title=Disparities in obesity prevalence due to variation in the retail food environment: Three testable hypotheses |journal=Nutrition Reviews |volume=66 |issue=4 |pages=216–28 |year=2008 |last1=Ford |first1=Paula B |last2=Dzewaltowski |first2=David A }}</ref> Research by Mari Gallagher found African Americans to be farther from healthful foods than other racial groups.<ref>Examining the Impact of Food Deserts on Public Health in Chicago, Mari Gallagher Research & Consulting Group, 2006. Retrieved from http://www.marigallagher.com/projects/4/</ref><ref>Examining the Impact of Food Deserts on Public Health in Detroit, Mari Gallagher Research & Consulting Group, 2007. Retrieved from http://www.marigallagher.com/projects/2/</ref><ref>''Women and Children Last'' (In the Food Desert), Mari Gallagher Research & Consulting Group, 2007</ref> Supermarkets in African American neighborhoods are just 52% as prevalent as in white neighborhoods.<ref name=pmid22005633>{{cite journal |pmid=22005633 |pmc=3221579 |year=2011 |author1=Leone |first1=A. F. |title=Store type and demographic influence on the availability and price of healthful foods, Leon County, Florida, 2008 |journal=Preventing Chronic Disease |volume=8 |issue=6 |pages=A140 |last2=Rigby |first2=S |last3=Betterley |first3=C |last4=Park |first4=S |last5=Kurtz |first5=H |last6=Johnson |first6=M. A. |last7=Lee |first7=J. S. }}</ref> Moreover, a review of food-frequency data in the [[Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities]] study revealed that dominantly white populations had five times more supermarkets than neighborhoods that were dominantly non-white.<ref name="Morland Obesity">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2005.11.003 |pmid=16530621 |title=Supermarkets, Other Food Stores, and Obesity |journal=American Journal of Preventive Medicine |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=333–9 |year=2006 |last1=Morland |first1=Kimberly |last2=Diez Roux |first2=Ana V. |last3=Wing |first3=Steve }}</ref> African Americans who lived in the same census tract with supermarket access were more likely to meet dietary guidelines for fruit and vegetable consumption. Each additional supermarket increased fruit and vegetable intake by 32%.<ref name="Morland Obesity"/>
A 2010 study analyzed data from the Centers for Disease Control and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to assess the health outcomes of women participating in SNAP and the [[Temporary Assistance for Needy Families]] program.<ref name ="Cheese">{{cite journal |first1=Michael |last1=Correll |year=2010 |title=Getting Fat on Government Cheese: The Connection Between Social Welfare Participation, Gender, and Obesity in America |url=http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1183&context=djglp |journal=Duke Journal of Gender Law & Policy |volume=18 |pages=45–77 |ssrn=1921920 }}</ref> The study primarily critically assessed the structure of current social welfare policies, but noted that 25% of food stamp program participants lack easy access to a supermarket.
A 2008 report claimed that in the [[Chicago metropolitan area]], African-American neighborhoods lack independent and chain supermarkets unlike Hispanic communities, although none are full-service chains. However, between 2005–2007, more discount stores did move into African-American communities.<ref name="Block">{{cite web |last1=Block|first1=Daniel |last2=Chavez|first2=Noel |last3=Birgen|first3=Judy | title=Finding Food in Chicago and the Suburbs, A Report of the Northeastern Illinois Community Food Security Assessment to the Public|date=June 2008 |url=https://www.csu.edu/nac/documents/FindingFoodinChicagoandtheSuburbsReporttothePublic2008.pdf |publisher=Chicago State University Neighborhood Assistance Center |location=Chicago, IL |page=34 |accessdate=July 20, 2016}}</ref> Hispanic communities in food deserts have targeted Hispanic food markets.<ref name="Food Deserts in Chicago">{{cite web |author=Illinois Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights|title=Food Deserts in Chicago |date=October 2011 |url=http://www.usccr.gov/pubs/IL-FoodDeserts-2011.pdf |publisher=United States Commission on Civil Rights |location=Washington, DC |page=7 }}</ref>
==== Proposed solutions ==== ===== Transportation initiatives ===== The USDA released an extensive report to Congress in 2009 as a request to reform the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008. Study recommendations for addressing access issues in food deserts included the above options as well as transportation reforms.<ref name="VerPloeg2009"/> Where growing vehicle availability is insufficient, better public transportation in rural food deserts or promoting safe walking and biking environments in urban areas may help.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="Morton2007" /> Proposed solutions include utilizing a combination of public and private resources.<ref name="Morton2007" /> Current transit assistance and meal-provisioning programs that are already established in many communities, such Meals on Wheels, have initiatives that focus on providing food residents with limited mobility and ability to shop at traditional food retailers.<ref>Meals on Wheels Association of America. (2011). The rural initiative. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://www.mowaa.org/page.aspx?pid=244 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090215050805/http://www.mowaa.org/Page.aspx?pid=244 |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}.</ref>
===== Incentivizing supermarket and grocery store number ===== {{main|Supermarket_shortage#Case_studies}} State and local governments are implementing public-private partnerships that use a combination of financing initiatives and community-level interventions to target areas with lower healthy food access.<ref name="VerPloeg2009" /> The progenitor program was Pennsylvania's Fresh Food Financing Initiative, a public-private partnership started in 2004 with state seed funds.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2009.0740 |pmid=20194989|title=Policy solutions to the 'grocery gap' |journal=Health Aff (Millwood) |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages=473–480 |year=2010 |last1=Story |first1=A|last2=Manon |first2=M |last3=Treuhaft |first3=S|last4=Giang |first4=T|last5=Harries |first5=C|last6=McCoubrey |first6=K}}</ref><ref name="Harries">{{cite journal |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2009.0740 |pmid=24594793 |pmc=4204010|title=Moving From Policy to Implementation: A Methodology and Lessons Learned to Determine Eligibility for Healthy Food Financing Projects|journal=J Public Health Manag Pract |volume=20 |issue=5|pages=498–505 |year=2014 |last1=Story |first1=Caroline |last2=Harries|first2=Julia |last3=Koprak |first3=Candace |last4=Weiss|first4=Stephanie |last5=Parker|first5=Kathryn M|last6=Karpyn|first6=Allison }}</ref> Success of the initiative led to the creation of similar programs in at least seven states and cities, like the New York City Food Retail Expansion to Support Health (FRESH) program.<ref name="Harries"/> In early 2010 the Obama administration unveiled the related [https://www.acf.hhs.gov/ocs/programs/community-economic-development/healthy-food-financing Healthy Food Financing Initiative].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hhs.gov/news/press/2010pres/02/20100219a.html |title=Obama Administration Details Healthy Food Financing Initiative (Archived copy) |publisher=U.S. Department of Health & Human Services |accessdate=2013-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801224105/http://www.hhs.gov/news/press/2010pres/02/20100219a.html |date=2010|archivedate=2013-08-01 |df= }}</ref>
Universities have coordinated with local business and community leaders to solve food scarcity issues. In 2008, [[La Salle University]] and [[The Fresh Grocer]] teamed up to open a grocery store in [[Germantown, Philadelphia]]. The Germantown neighborhood was plagued with a decades-long food desert, but thanks to a coordination between two enterprises, the Fresh Grocer was able to provide more than 250 jobs to Philadelphians and provide healthy food.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.progressivegrocer.com/la-salle-university-fresh-grocer-opens-today|title=La Salle University Fresh Grocer Opens Today – ProgressiveGrocer|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2009-08-22/news/25276116_1_supermarket-shoprite-pizza-shops |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160623203310/http://articles.philly.com/2009-08-22/news/25276116_1_supermarket-shoprite-pizza-shops |archivedate=2016-06-23 |df= }}</ref>
===== Community/family help =====
Families often work together and develop a network of sharing<ref name="auto1">{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/088610999801300206 |title=Income Packaging as a Survival Strategy for Welfare Mothers |journal=Affilia |volume=13 |issue=2 |pages=211–32 |year=1998 |last1=Miranne |first1=K. B. }}</ref><ref name="auto2">{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/088610999501000404 |title=Women of the Shadows: Appalachian Women's Participation in the Informal Economy |journal=Affilia |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=398–412 |year=1995 |last1=McInnis-Dittrich |first1=K. }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/All_Our_Kin.html?id=4R9HAAAAMAAJ|title=All Our Kin|isbn=978-0060904241|author1=Stack|first1=Carol B|year=1975 |publisher=Harper |location=New York, NY}}</ref> to exchange clothing, provide childcare, sell personal possessions, and share transportation resources and even housing. People living in food deserts often use this approach to feed their families.<ref name="auto1" /><ref name="auto2" />
===== Foodsheds ===== {{Main|Foodshed}} Foodshed planning is an integral part of policy for not only New York, but other cities such as Chicago, Toronto and Cincinnati. <ref>{{cite web |first1=Nevin |last1= Cohen |first2=Nicholas|last2= Freudenberg |first3=Craig|last3= Willingham |date=April 24, 2017 |title= Growing a Regional Food Shed in New York: Lessons from Chicago, Toronto and Cincinnati|publisher=City University of New York Urban Food Policy Institute |location=New York, NY|url=http://www.cunyurbanfoodpolicy.org/news/2017/4/19/regional-food-in-other-cities |access-date=July 20, 2017 }}</ref> Columbia University's 2010 New York City Regional Foodshed Initiative set out to analyze local food production capacity of the Metropolitan Region as part of a strategy to increase availability of affordable, healthful food in all neighborhoods.<ref>{{cite web |first=Vanessa Espaillat |last=Bonnelly |date=January 28, 2010 |title=The New York City Regional Foodshed |url=http://urbandesignlab.columbia.edu/projects/food-and-the-urban-environment/nyc-regional-food-shed-initiative/|publisher=Columbia University The Earth Institute Urban Design Lab |location=New York, NY |access-date=July 20, 2017 }}</ref> Some projects increase the availability of healthy affordable food by establishing community-run markets, farmers markets, mobile grocery carts or stores, and urban agriculture projects.<ref name="VerPloeg2009" />
====== Farmers' markets ====== {{further|Farmers'_market#Canada_and_United_States}} Some [[Local food|food movements]] hold that locally grown food at farmers' markets is superior to that typically in supermarkets.<ref name="Donovan">{{cite journal |title=Best Practices & Challenges for Farmers Market Incentive Programs: A Guide for Policymakers & Practitioners |journal=The Graduate Journal of Food Studies |url=https://gradfoodstudies.org/2016/06/30/best-practices-challenges-for-farmers-market-incentive-programs-a-guide-for-policymakers-practitioners/ |volume=1 |number=1|year=2016 |last1= Donovan |first1=Jeanie |last2= Madore |first2= Amy |last3= Randall |first3= Megan |last4= Vickery |first4= Kate }}</ref> However, these markets are often too costly for the budget-conscious.<ref name="pmid22005633" /> Government programs like SNAP and WIC often in partnership with nonprofit organizations subsidize low-income individuals to purchase produce from farmers' markets.{{sfn|Ver Ploeg|2009|p=107}}<ref name="Donovan"/>
In rural Bertie County, the poorest county in North Carolina, community members in conjunction with a public high school class designed and constructed a pavilion to serve as a home for a local farmers' market.<ref>{{cite web |last=Schwartz |first=Ariel |year=2011 |title=High school students build a farmer's market in a food desert |publisher=Fast Company |url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/1678622/high-school-students-build-a-farmers-market-in-a-food-desert }}</ref>
====== Community gardens ====== {{main|Community gardening in the United States}}
Community involvement and the incorporation of local organizations and volunteerism can improve the effectiveness of food safety nets and alternative solutions such as community gardens (''e.g.'', see [[Urban agriculture in West Oakland]]).<ref name="smithmorton" />
===== Internet stores ===== {{further|Online_food_ordering#Food_cooperatives}} {{further|Online food ordering#Timeline of online food delivery}} Internet delivery options overcome distance barriers in food deserts with [[meal kit]] services and [[online shopping]] for fresh groceries from retailers and food cooperatives.
State and federal agencies in New York created a program to allow food stamp recipients the option to purchase healthful foods online for home delivery. In the fall of 2016 this pilot program was launched in conjunction with an established food delivery company, FreshDirect, for two zip codes in the Bronx. The hope is that online food delivery can eliminate food deserts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.foodstamps.org/articles/article/2014/04/11/use-your-ebt-to-shop-for-groceries-online|title=Use Your EBT to Shop for Groceries Online|last=FoodStamps|website=www.foodstamps.org|access-date=2016-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.freshdirect.com/browse.jsp?id=about_ebt|title=FreshDirect – About EBT at FreshDirect|website=FreshDirect|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref>
===== Education ===== {{main|Nutrition_Education}} {{main|Nutrition#Advice_and_guidance}} Research suggests that food deserts are not the real problem, eating habits are.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/takes-grocery-store-eliminate-food-desert/|title=Why it takes more than a grocery store to eliminate a 'food desert'|work=PBS NewsHour|access-date=2017-03-21|language=en-US}}</ref> Indeed, one study found that 89.3% of people in a community were either "highly interested" or "interested" in education on preparing healthier food options.<ref name="auto">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.jada.2011.06.298|title=Community Food Assessment in an Urban Food Desert|journal=Journal of the American Dietetic Association|volume=111|issue=9|pages=A82|year=2011|last1=Braunstein|first1=N.S.|last2=Ewell|first2=J.B.|last3=Santos|first3=C.|last4=Palmer|first4=A.M.}}</ref> Avenues to increase education and outreach about diet and health by the federal government include <ref name=":0" /> the [http://www.fns.usda.gov/snap/supplemental-nutrition-assistance-program-education-snap-ed SNAP Education (SNAP-Ed)] and [https://nifa.usda.gov/program/expanded-food-and-nutrition-education-program-efnep Expanded Food and Nutrition Education Program (EFNEP)].

A '''foreign area officer''' ('''FAO''') is a [[officer (armed forces)|commissioned officer]] from any of the five branches of the [[United States Armed Forces]] who is a regionally focused expert in [[politics|political]]-[[military]] operations. Such officers possess a unique combination of strategic focus and regional expertise, with political, [[culture|cultural]], [[sociology|sociological]], [[economy|economic]], and [[geography|geographic]] awareness. Foreign language proficiency is an unequivocal necessity in at least one of the dominant languages in their specified region.
A FAO will typically serve overseas tours as a [[Military attaché|defense attaché]], a [[United States Security Assistance Organizations|security assistance officer]], or as a political-military planner in a service's headquarters, [[Joint Chiefs of Staff|Joint Staff]], [[Major Command]]s, [[Unified Combatant Command]]s, or in agencies of the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]. They also serve as [[arms control]] specialists, country desk officers, [[liaison officer]]s, and [[Exchange officer|Military Personnel Exchange Program (MPEP)]] officer to host nation or coalition allies. Recently, increasing numbers of FAOs are serving as political and cultural advisors to combatant staffs in support of the [[Iraq War]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]]. Presently, there are just over 2,200 FAOs in active operational capacities, while roughly 25 percent are still in training. The services plan to recruit and train more than 170 a year, with almost 1,100 new FAOs entering the program by 2014.<ref>Department of Defense. “Defense Language Transformation Roadmap” 2005.</ref>
Roles and responsibilities of FAOs are extensive and varied. They advise senior leaders on political-military operations and relations with other nations, provide cultural expertise to forward-deployed commands conducting military operations, build and maintain long-term relationships with foreign leaders, develop and coordinate security cooperation, execute security assistance programs with host nations, and develop reports on diplomatic, information, military, and economic activities.
==Army== The Army Foreign Area Officer Program (Functional area 48) is a single-track FAO program managed by G-35, SSF, which is the Strategic Leadership Division. It is by far the largest and oldest FAO program of the Services. The Proponent Office is responsible for establishing policy guidance and FAO career field development as well as establishing specific programs focused on the accession, training, education, distribution, utilization, deployment, and separation of FAOs. Currently, there are 1,257 Army FAOs either in training or fully qualified.
Army FAOs are categorized by areas of concentration that correspond with their respective [[List of United States Army careers|military occupational specialty]], further grouped in scope by functional areas. Army FAOs are divided into nine categories of regional areas of expertise and language skills:<ref name="DODD 1315.17">{{cite web|url=http://www.dtic.mil/whs/directives/corres/pdf/131517p.pdf|title=Department of Defense Directive 1315.17 - Service Foreign Area Officer (FAO) Programs|last=Wolfowitz|first=Paul|authorlink=Paul Wolfowitz|date=April 28, 2005|work=[[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense|Deputy Secretary of Defense]]|publisher=United States Department of Defense|accessdate=20 April 2010}}</ref> * 48B - [[Latin America]] * 48D – [[South Asia]] * 48E – [[Eurasia]] * 48F – [[China]] * 48G – [[Middle East]] * 48H – [[Northeast Asia]] * 48I – [[Southeast Asia]] * 48J – [[Africa]], [[Sub-Saharan Africa|south]] of the [[Sahara]]
==Marine Corps== The International Affairs Officer Program replaced the FAO and International Relations Officer Program in the Marine Corps in 2000, which is an umbrella program that governs two separate, but interrelated [[List of United States Marine Corps MOS|military occupational specialty]]: the Foreign Area Officer (994x) and the Regional Affairs Officer (982x) designations. Much like the USAF dual-track system, RAOs are basically FAOs without local language skills. There are approximately 280 FAOs and 80 RAOs in the Marine Corps, distributed amongst the following specialties:<ref name="Proceedings">{{cite web|url=http://www.donhcs.com/hsr/20_october/doc/Boraz%20Behind%20the%20Curve%20culture%20centric%20skills.pdf|title=Behind the Curve in Culture-Centric Skills|last=Boraz|first=[[Lieutenant commander (United States)|LCDR]] Steven C.|date=June 2005|publisher=[[Proceedings (magazine)|Proceedings]]|accessdate=20 April 2010}}</ref> * 9821 – RAO Latin America * 9822 – RAO [[Post-Soviet states|former Soviet Union]] * 9823 - RAO China * 9824 – RAO Middle East/[[North Africa]] * 9825 – RAO [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] * 9826 – RAO [[Western Asia|Southwest Asia]] * 9827 – [[Western Europe]] * 9828 – [[East Asia|Eastern Asia]] (excluding China) * 9829 – RAO [[Eastern Europe]] (excluding former Soviet Union) * 9940 – Basic FAO * 9941 – FAO Latin America * 9942 – FAO Former Soviet Union * 9943 – FAO China * 9944 – FAO Middle East/North Africa * 9945 – FAO Sub-Saharan Africa * 9946 – FAO Southwest Asia * 9947 – FAO Western Europe * 9948 – FAO East Asia (excluding China) * 9949 – FAO Eastern Europe (excluding former Soviet Union)
==Navy== The Navy FAO Branch is a [[Restricted Line Officer|restricted line]] community of the Navy.<ref name="OPNAVINST 1301.10B">{{cite web|url=http://doni.daps.dla.mil/Directives/01000%20Military%20Personnel%20Support/01-300%20Assignment%20and%20Distribution%20Services/1301.10B.pdf|title=OPNAVINST 1301.10B Navy Foreign Area Officer (FAO) Program|last=Morgan Jr.|first=[[Vice admiral (United States)|VADM]] John G.|date=May 4, 2006|work=Deputy Chief of Naval Operations (Plans, Policy, and Operations)|publisher=United States Navy|accessdate=20 April 2010}}</ref> The Navy has approximately 350 FAOs either fully qualified or in training. The community is expected to achieve 400 officers by 2019. As with the Army, the Navy has a single-track system, where officers from other Navy communities transfer over to Foreign Area Officer permanently. Navy FAOs are assigned the 1710 [[List of Naval Officer Designators|designator]].
Navy FAOs are apportioned amongst the five regional [[Unified Combatant Command]]s: * [[United States European Command]] * [[United States Central Command]] * [[United States Africa Command]] * [[United States Pacific Command]] * [[United States Southern Command]]
==Air Force== The International Affairs Specialist Program is the Air Force component, and encompasses two officer types: the Regional Affairs Strategist and Political-Military Affairs Strategist. Both tracks remain under the [[Air Force Specialty Code]] 16: 16F for RAS and 16P for PAS. PAS development begins in conjunction with Intermediate Developmental Education, and officers serve in similar positions as RAS officers do, but perform duties that require a broad knowledge of political-military affairs rather than regional expertise with foreign language skills.<ref name="DOAP 600–3">{{cite web|url=http://www.army.mil/usapa/epubs/pdf/p600_3.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031224121220/http://www.army.mil/usapa/epubs/pdf/p600_3.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 24, 2003 |title=Department of the Army Pamphlet 600–3: Commissioned Officer Professional Development and Career Management |last=Casey, Jr. |first=GEN George W. |authorlink=George W. Casey, Jr. |date=February 1, 2010 |work=[[Chief of Staff of the United States Army]] |publisher=United States Army |accessdate=20 April 2010 }}</ref> RAS officers are distributed amongst the following subcategories:<ref>http://static.e-publishing.af.mil/production/1/af_a3_5/publication/afi16-109/afi16-109.pdf</ref> * A – Attaché * B – Central Asia/East Europe/Russia * C – Latin America * D – East Asia/China * E – Southeast Asia * F – Middle East/North Africa * G – Sub-Saharan Africa * H – Western Europe * J - South Asia * K - China * L - Generalist
==Accession & training== Acceptance into the FAO programs typically requires at least 7–10 years of commissioned service, since most FAO positions are designated for that of a field-grade officer (Marines being the exception, who only require 3 years). The FAO accession process is lengthy process and requires meticulous review of every candidate applying. While all DoD branches are in the process of expanding their FAO (or FAO equivalent) Programs, FAO accession remains one of the most highly competitive processes of the US military.{{fact|date=April 2010}} On average, more than eight candidates compete for every single FAO slot available. Generally speaking, applicants must have at a minimum the following: * [[Classified information in the United States|Top secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information]] [[security clearance]], (or at least be eligible) * Primary MOS or warfare area qualification * Broad military experience in their assigned MOS * A score of 95 or better on the [[Defense Language Aptitude Battery]] or a [[Defense Language Proficiency Tests]] score of 2/2. * 2.7 [[Grade (education)|GPA]] or higher (on a scale of 4.0) with an [[undergraduate degree]] * Must have a [[U.S. uniformed services pay grades|pay-grade of O3]] or above
FAO training varies amongst all four DoD branches, but usually takes a minimum of 3–5 years before FAOs can utilize their skills in an operational capacity, depending upon the qualifications of the candidate at the time of accession. * 1 year at the [[Naval Postgraduate School]] in [[Monterey, California]] where a graduate degree is completed in [[national security]] affairs with an emphasis on the target region. * Foreign Area Officer Orientation Course, a 3-day introductory course into their career path. * 6 - 15 months of basic language training, depending upon the language(s) selected and the level of difficulty, at either the [[Defense Language Institute]] Foreign Language Center in Monterey or Defense Language Institute-[[Washington, D.C.|Washington]]. * 6-12 months conducting in-country training for area familiarization, language enrichment, professional development in the target region, etc. * Subsequent FAO tours.
A long road exists between accession and full FAO qualification. It takes between 3–5 years of training, education, and actual FAO tour performance before FAO trainees are ever even considered for full designation and qualification as an FAO. Standard requirements of fully qualified FAOs generally include the following: * Advanced degree(s) with a regional focus. * Defense Language Proficiency Test score of 2 in listening and 2 in reading, and a goal of 1+ in speaking. * Regional Expertise at a level 3 or above, per [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs]] Instruction 3126.01. * Defense Language Aptitude Battery general score of 95 (prior to being considered for acceptance into the FAO program). * Top Secret / Sensitive Compartmented Information clearance. * [[Joint Professional Military Education]] Phase 1 complete (if applicable, typically for Navy and Marines). * Overseas assignment and screening clearance. * At least one overseas FAO tour in progress or completed.
The [[Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness]] is the proponent for FAO programs for the DoD. He or she establishes DoD accession, education, and utilization policy for Foreign Area Officers. FAO guidance, directives, and standards for all military branch FAO programs are promulgated by DoD Directive 1315.17.<ref name="DODD 1315.17" /> The [[Under Secretary of Defense for Policy]] and the [[Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence]] oversees FAO capabilities, needs, and utilization in the DoD Agencies that they respectively supervise. For combat support activities, such oversight is conducted in conjunction with the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The [[Defense Language Office]] ensures a strategic focus on meeting present and future requirements for language and regional expertise, among military and civilian employees. This office's main responsibilities are to oversee and manage the implementation of a comprehensive Department-wide Language Transformation Roadmap; identify policy, procedural, and resource needs associated with providing needed language capability; oversee policy regarding the development, management, and utilization of civilian employees and members of the Armed Forces; and conduct research and analyze studies, reports, and lessons learned from the Global War on Terrorism and current military operations as they pertain to language and regional area expertise.
==Leadership== While promotion levels vary between the branches, retention rates of FAOs are higher than service averages.{{fact|date=April 2010}} The bulk of the FAO community is primarily composed of [[Field officer|field grade officers]], though [[General officer|general]] and [[flag officer]]s include [[General (United States)|General]] [[John Abizaid]], [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] [[Christopher G. Cavoli]], Lieutenant General [[Karl Eikenberry]], Lieutenant General [[Keith Dayton]], Major General Charles Hooper, Major General [[Robin Fontes]], Brigadier General Richard M. Lake, Brigadier General Henry Nowak, Brigadier General Mark O’Neill, Brigadier General Kevin Ryan, Brigadier General John Adams, and Rear Admiral Douglas Venlet.
==See also== * [[Defense Language Institute]] * [[Defense Language Aptitude Battery]] * [[Defense Language Proficiency Tests]]
